Riemannian geometry
5. Riemannian geometry

The much more significant change came with the arrival of Bernhard
Riemann’s great extension of Gaussian differential geometry.
Precisely, he found a way to define geometries starting from very
general concepts, and gradually leading (through more and more narrow
hypotheses) to the known metric geometries. At the risk of sounding
anachronistic, it can be argued that Riemann’s
“conceptual” style of work is a form of
proto-structuralism. What he does is this: first, he introduces the
general structure of n-dimensional manifold, to then define a metric
in the manifold (with the means of differential geometry, line element
and Gaussian curvature). With all this in place, Euclidean and
non-Euclidean geometries emerge as particular cases of 3-dimensional
manifolds, concrete forms of the general structure. And the
“hypothesis” that singles out these geometries, within the
general framework of Riemannian manifolds, is the physical assumption
that rigid bodies can move freely without deformation.

Some of the epistemological issues are already raised with
Gauss’s work (1828), so we turn to it first. Euler had shown
long before that, at each point P in a (smooth) surface, there
are two so-called principal curvatures, the maximum and the
minimum curvature of lines passing through P. These curvatures,
\(\kappa_{1}\) and \(\kappa_{2}\), occur in plane sections
perpendicular to each other and allow us to study the shape of the
entire neighborhood of P. Now, Gauss’s deep idea (which remarkably he
found while working on geodesy, i.e., surveying and mapmaking) was
that some properties of curved surfaces can be studied without regard
for the ambient space. And one of these key properties is the product
\(\kappa_{1}\kappa_{2}\), called the Gaussian curvature of the surface
(at a point). Thus, employing methods of differential analysis, he
elaborated what is called an intrinsic geometry of surfaces. 
 Gauss worked with coordinate systems within the surface
itself, and considered the distance between points on the surface S
along lines contained entirely in S. Now, some surfaces
\(S_1\), \(S_2\) can be obtained from each other by bending (without
stretching); expressed more formally, there is an isometric map
from \(S_1\) to \(S_2\), which means that the points on
\(S_1\) are assigned points in \(S_2\) so that distances within the
surface \(S_1\) are the same as the distances of the corresponding
points in \(S_2\). (For instance, a plane can be so bent to form of
cylinder; you may use a piece of paper to convince yourself.)  And
Gauss made the remarkable discovery that the Gaussian curvature of a
surface is an intrinsic property that remains invariant under
isometric mappings. He was so happy about this result that he called
it theorema eggregium, his ‘outstanding theorem’:
if two surfaces \(S_1\), \(S_2\) are isometric, then corresponding
points have the same Gaussian curvature. 

The fact that the Gaussian curvature of a surface at a point is
intrinsic means that it is entirely determined by measurements
in the surface and does not involve any question of a third
dimension or the ambient space embedding the surface. The property of
Gaussian curvature does not depend on how the surface is located in
space, but only on intrinsic properties of its metrics. That is to
say, important properties of curved surfaces remain invariant even if
one bends the surface isometrically (without breaking, stretching, or
folding it up). One such thing that remains invariant is the
geodesics on the surface, i.e., the lines of shortest distance
(lying entirely on the surface). In the case of a cylinder, the
geodesics are the vertical lines, horizontal lines (circles), and
helices around it —and these lines all come from straight lines
on the plane that is ‘rolled up’ to form the cylinder. 

Given a metric, a differential formula for the distance ds
between neighboring points (which is everywhere the same), the
curvature can be found. If, for example, the formula for distance is
that for a map of the sphere on the plane, the curvature will be found
to be the reciprocal of the square of the radius of the sphere
\(1/R^2\). A plane has the same Gaussian curvature as a cylinder, or
also as something close to a cone (that one may form from a cylinder,
without breaking, stretching, or folding); they are locally isometric;
although curved, the cylinder has zero curvature in Gauss’s
technical sense, just as does the plane, which is why printing from a
rotating drum is possible. Gauss investigated when one surface can be
mapped onto another in such a way that distances are not altered,
showing that a necessary condition for this to happen is that the
curvatures at corresponding points are the same. And this also implies
that the same figures can be constructed on all of these surfaces; the
minimal lines or curves of shortest length between two points
(geodesics) on one surface correspond to those on the others, so that
angles, areas, etc. will be the same. Gauss had found a deeper way to
look into the geometry of a surface, and this gave birth to modern
differential geometry.

It was not immediately appreciated that Gauss’s approach allowed
mathematicians to define surfaces as regions of the plane with a
particular metric that are not to be obtained from surfaces in
Euclidean 3-dimensional space. If one defines a surface as
the image of a map from a piece of \(\mathbb{R}^2\) to
\(\mathbb{R}^3\), then of course it is in \(\mathbb{R}^3\). But if one
defines a surface as a region of \(\mathbb{R}^2\) with a particular
metric, then there may be no surface in \(\mathbb{R}^3\) to which it
corresponds. The first person to appreciate this seems to have been
Riemann, who also extended this idea to any number of dimensions.
